label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, July 17, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, wondering at the construction of the traffic patterns on Hawaii and describing a dinner he and Morris had attended at a friends house where his wife had showed them a series of old photographs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
23
July 17, 1943
Dear Gertie, 
How are the plans coming along for the big invasion. You are
proxbably having Rose pack everything into trunks, take them out again
because the trunks or trunk is too heavy and starting at the beggining
again. I know how difficult it is to have to try and bring clothes for
hot and cold weather, dinning out and day use and my sympathy goes out to
you. Uniforms are so easy. One always wears the same thing, and there
is never the necessity to change or worry whether you are looking your
best. You have the rather dubious satisfaction of knowing that you are
always looking your worse.
The road system being constructed from Honolulu to the Navy Yard
fascinates me. The only possible way that it could hare been conceived is
that they gave a very drunken man a pencil and paper and asked him to
draw a system of interlocking roads that would cause as many accidents as
possible. While the accidents are ssured there is the extra thrill of
seeing the lengths that they have gone to in order that cars shall meet
suddenly without any warning in sideways collisions, while some of the
arrangements for bang up head on crashes are superb. Even with bad luck and
few cars on the road, a condition that obviously will not occur out here,
the daily take should be at least one hundred accidents. Just before you arrive a
at the Navy Yard there is a hinterland of cross roads a veritible jungle of
interlacing highways bisected by a railroad. This is indeed the happy
Hunting Ground, and a tractor and crane are kept in constant attendance
to lift the wrecks up and remove them form the scene. Into this wild melee
we plunge every morning in the little red car. To the tune of rasping fenders
and the shrill high not[e]of interlocking bumbers we go under and over the
top of everything. If you were only here for one mornings ride, you would
decorate all of the Passengers with the congressional medal for outstanding
bravery in the face of the greatest possible danger to life and limb.
Last night Duke Kohanamoku asked us to dinner or rather supper.
We had just finished swimming and were about to go home and cook when he
said come on back and have spaggetti with me. It was a most delightful evening.
His wife Nadine, who is very nice, cooked the spaggetti and a wonderful sauce
of meet and tomatoes while Duke gathered tiny little tomatoes in his victory
garden. By the time the spaggetti was ready we had pured the tomatoes ontop
of [the] lettuce and all sat down with a bottle of red wine and the biggest plates
of spaggettiX you have ever seen. We were gathered around a tiny table in the
kitchenand ocassionaly I found myself at one end of a strin of Spaggettin and
Morris at the other end. There was also a cat that Duke said followed
[End Page 1]
him everywhere, but I did not c sider this a comp liment as it was the
ra[t]ties looking cat I have ever seen. The body was white and the tail and
carts were black. Depending on what he was leaning up against you thought
it was a cat without a tail and ears or a cat with only two ears and tail and
no body. After dinner Nadine showed us pictures of Duke while he washed
the dishes dressed in a lava lava. You know one of those gay colored clothes
wrapped around the waist.
There were pictures of him in his racing days. At one time he
held something like twelve world records. You have never seen such a physique
in your life. Really beautiful. Then there were hilarious picutres of
him when he was acting in the moveis. Dressed as a deep sea diver, a Turk,
an indian in a massere of the cowboys etc. He told a story of how he was
supposed to be an Indian Chief and was all dressed up in a bigh head dress
of feathers. Riding to the top of a hill he peered out with hand shaded eyes.
Down below he saw the enemy. United States Troups. Waving to his tribesmen
who were still down below the surface of the ridge on the fa r side he
started down to meet his foes. All of a sudden there was a roar of hoofs
and he found he was behind his five hundred tirbesmen who had galloped
past. The director stopped the scene and told him that while it was
probably the thing to do in war to be behind his troops nevertheless
in the movies an Indian Chief had to be at the head of his attacking braves.
Duke also described how some of the movies were made showing fights between
a man and a shark. The shark was in a big pool of water and the man
next to the pool but not in it. The camera was located on the far side of
the pool so that it took thepicutre through the water. The man who was
not in water at all wonderful passes at the shark when he swam up to the
glass to see what was going on. This man would fall on his hack. Jump up
in the air and wave his knife etc. and it all looked OK when the picure was [scratched through]
shown. The picutres were all very amusing that he showed us because they
were of moving picutrex actresss and men back in 1913. Anita Stewart etc.
You have never seen such funny looking clothes in all your life. I had
forgotten that people ever dressed like that. Also I really belive that
women have changed their shapes since those days. At that time they all
had b[ig] stomacks, funny figures etc. Then there [were] pictures of the days
in Honolulu before the war. Days when the islands were crowded with movie
stars and notables. He told stories of the wealth that was poured out.
Men and women would ask the beach boys what they wanted. No matter what they
asked for they were given. He told of one man, a co per king who went out
in a canoe with some of the boys and when they had come ashore said what
would you like. One said a guitar, another a camera and a third, a house and
garden. Each received what he had asked for. The sky was the limit.
Can you imagine how spoiled those bo[y]s were and the trouble that
everyone had with them.
Goodbye sweeheart, hope I hear from you soon, although I must
say I received a lettcr on the twelth, so I have no kick coming. All my
love.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
